posts.author: darktooth
posts.content:
From the nwnwiki: “multiple sources of regeneration are simultaneously active, each healing its set amount of hit points when its timer is up (not the sum of all regeneration sources being added at once)”

Now assume that a PC has amassed maximum regeneration from items (+1760 hp). Will there be a window that he can die if attacked asynchronously by a horde of enemies? If so, can a healing spell like cure minor wounds improve his chances of survival?

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content: I'm afraid I don't quite understand your question darktooth.

posts.content:
darktooth wrote:

From the nwnwiki: “multiple sources of regeneration are simultaneously active, each healing its set amount of hit points when its timer is up (not the sum of all regeneration sources being added at once)”

Yes, if the enemies can do more damage than one can regen.
If so, can a healing spell like cure minor wounds improve his chances of survival?
That depends on how much damage one is taking vs how much one is healed.

posts.author: darktooth
posts.content:
Mick Dagger wrote:
Dec 16, 2022
I'm afraid I don't quite understand your question darktooth.
Yeah my question was quite confusing. But basically, I am assuming that the PC in my example has base hit points that is well below the amount of damage that he receives from attacking enemies, but he relies on items that give him +1760 HP regeneration. To restate my question, how often does the game check for a character's hit points within a combat round? If the PC heals itself, would it somehow help, or does the amount of regeneration he receives in a round override any benefit?

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
As I said, it depends.

First of all, you would really need to have those cures on haste, to allow for them to supersede the regen (which procs once a round, down at the bottom of the round).  Otherwise, it will probably not really matter much.

It COULD make a difference, however.
